ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the book My Body. We learned about different parts of our bodies.
In this activity, we will look at pictures of different things, and sort them into two groups:

ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted.ac_teacher-speaking: Body Parts is for cards that show parts of the body.
Not Body Parts is for cards that show pictures of things that are not body parts.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach Hand Signals Ask children to give a thumbs up if the picture shows a body part or a thumbs down if it does not. Model.
Ask Show one picture card and ask the question on the back of the picture card, offering support or challenge as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend the conversation.
Sort Give the picture card to a child to sort into the “body parts” or “not body parts” groups.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: All of the photos on this side show body p (parts). What do you know about these body parts?

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-card_run-in_hed: Talk About Pictures that Are Not Body Parts
ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: All of these pictures show things that you wear on parts of your body but they are not body parts. Can you name other things that you wear?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Show children three picture cards at a time, where two are examples of body parts and the other is not (e.g., hand, foot, mitten). Ask, Which one doesn’t belong? Then ask, How do you know? Repeat with other groups of three cards.

Show children two Picture Cards at a time, where one is an example of a body part and the other is an example of what might be worn on that body part (e.g., hand and mitten). Ask, What is the same and what is different about these things? Repeat with other pairs of cards.

Encourage children to use a physical response, in addition to speaking. For example, invite children to point to their own hands, feet, and heads when these pictures are shown. These physical and visual cues will support language development, and children will be able to participate in the activity while their language skills grow.

Invite children to play this game in the large-group space or outdoors where they can hold the cards up near the different parts of their bodies. When students choose a card showing an object that is not a body part, they can shake their hand, foot, or head to show where the object is worn.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read My Body and we focused on following rules and routines about taking care of our bodies. Review reasons for classroom rules, such as taking turns and handling classroom materials with care.
We learned the word communicate. Let’s revisit that word since we will use it when we talk about the activity.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Use the communicate Vocabulary Card to revisit the word.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, we will look at pictures of people using different ways to communicate. We will discuss each picture and then answer questions about some routines we follow when we communicate.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card to the group and ask the question on the back of the picture card, offering support or challenge as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Show the next card and repeat the steps above.

Talk about Communication Rules Talk together about the different body parts we use when we communicate, including our brain. Encourage children to come up with more ways to communicate, and discuss rules involved, such as using your inside voice. Remind children that it is important for them to communicate what they need.

For younger children or children who are developmentally delayed, read aloud the Ask and Support sections of each card. Then invite children to tell what is happening in the photo and to say more about it. Encourage as much conversation as possible.

Encourage children to name messages that we use as part of our daily routines (for example, saying good morning or goodnight). Have students talk about ways we communicate to follow rules of politeness, such as saying, “please” and “thank you.”

Children whose first language is Spanish will recognize the Spanish cognate comunicar for the English word communicate. Help children make this connection if they have not done so already. Making this connection will help children’s vocabulary development as well as improve their participation in the activity.

Invite children to respond to the Picture Cards by drawing and writing about the ways people communicate on the cards. Discuss with children what body parts are involved with their own writing and drawing, and remind them that drawing and writing are also ways to communicate.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read My Body and we focused on what our brains do. We also reviewed details about food and our bodies, and we took a look at a glossary, which is a list of special words from the book, The glossary includes what the words mean.
In this activity, we will look at pictures of different body parts. We’ll ask and answer questions about what makes each body part important.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card of a body part to the group and discuss it. Ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Show the next card and repeat steps above.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-card_run-in_hed: Talk about Parts of the Body
ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: We’ve learned a lot about body parts and why different body parts are important. Now we can talk about how some body parts are alike and some are different. Use as many describing words as you can while we talk.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: For younger and developmentally delayed children, read aloud the Ask and Support section of each card. Then, ask children to tell what else they know about the body part. Encourage extended conversation.

Encourage children to talk about the different messages that get sent to and from the brain and each of the body parts. Have children talk about how the brain sends messages so that some parts will move and that different body parts send messages to the brain.

Encourage children to make a motion with each body part shown on the picture cards. For example, children can stretch their arms, gently kick their legs, nod their heads, pull on their ear, and open their eyes wide. This will help children develop stronger language skills.

Invite children to respond to the picture cards by drawing their own pictures of the body parts. They may want to represent the ways that body parts send messages to the brain. Support children as they talk about what they are drawing and encourage them to use describing words.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials You will need large sheets of drawing paper and drawing tools such as crayons and markers.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read Head, Shoulders, Knees, and Toes and we learned more about body parts.
We learned the words shoulders and knees. Let’s revisit those words since we will use them when we talk about the activity.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Use the shoulders and knees Vocabulary Cards to revisit the words.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, we will outline our whole bodies. Then you will color in the outlines. Then we will display our outlines.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Trace Trace the outline of each child’s body on butcher paper. Write the child’s name on the back of the paper.
Ask Ask children to use crayons or markers to draw on the outlines. They might draw their faces, clothes, and hair.
View Take the outlines and put them on the ground. Have children take a walk around to look at all the outlines.

Talk about Parts of the Body Invite children to talk about their body pictures. Encourage them to point to their knees and shoulders on their pictures, along with other body parts. Invite them to compare how they colored their outlines.

Support children as they color and draw on the outlines, encouraging them to name and tell more about the details they are working on. Invite them to tell you about what they are doing, and transcribe their words.

Encourage children who are ready for more of a challenge to tell you about all the body parts they see on the outline and to draw and color the eyes, nose, mouth, hair, hands, and feet. Then, encourage them to color an outfit they would like to have on the outline.

Let children have extra time to discuss their outlines and how they colored and drew on them. Encourage children to work in pairs to compare what they did with their outlines. Let children know that they can use all the languages they know when they talk with a child who knows the same languages.

If any of the children have physical issues that make it hard for them to have their bodies outlined, invite them to draw their own outline of their bodies on paper that is easy for them to handle. Help them as needed. Encourage them to color and draw on their outlines so that the pictures represent them.
